lesson-1.title: Creating an Account
lesson-1.details:
Before we start, you need an account to save your work.

  1. Create a CSDT account
  2. Learn about cultural backgrounds in discrete iteration tools
  3. Use programming to make several designs in these craft forms.
  4. Share your program with your teacher and peers

lesson-2.title: Cultural Background
lesson-2.details:
In this section we will use quilting to illustrate the ways that cultures created their own heritage algorithms. You can use the same approach with any of the tools on the CSDT website.In the Quilting Cultural Background you will see five sections, as illustrated to the left. Notice that if you click on 'Four Directions' you will see an additional four cultural groups to choose from. Go to the cultural tradition that your teacher assigns, and start your investigation!

For example, if you were assigned the Anishinaabe quilting tradition, you will notice they are arranged in circular patterns. We call these groups of patterns heritage algorithms because it shows how computing ideas were independently invented in each culture. The Anishinaabe heritage algorithm is circular because of something called the medicine wheel. But what that really means, and why it is so important, you will need to discover.

lesson-test.title: Stamping Test
lesson-test.details: Here is a first script for you to play with. It includes four blocks. The first block, When Clicked, is used to start your code. The second block, clear, is used to clear the screen. We use stamp to paste the image onto the screen. And lastly, glide by steps 100 is used to move the image on the screen. You can change the number in the glide block to make the image glide any number of steps. Now that you know what each block does, can you make it glide by more? Less? Make it glide backwards?

lesson-3.title: Stamping
lesson-3.details: Here is a first script for you to play with. It includes four blocks. The first block, When Clicked, is used to start your code. The second block, clear, is used to clear the screen. We use stamp to paste the image onto the screen. And lastly, glide by steps 100 is used to move the image on the screen. You can change the number in the glide block to make the image glide any number of steps. Now that you know what each block does, can you make it glide by more? Less? Make it glide backwards?

lesson-4.title: Changing Costumes
lesson-4.details: We call each image a costume. We say there is a sprite switching costumes on the stage. Inside the switch costume block you can click on the drop-down menu. Find a new set of 3 costumes and get the sprite to stamp them onto the stage.

lesson-5.title: Changing Costume Color
lesson-5.details: You can change the color of costume by entering numbers, in the range of 0-100, in the space provided next to ‘change [color] effect by___.’ You can switch to different costumes and set different colors for each costume. Can you set different colors for the costumes you chose above?

lesson-6.title: Changing Costume Size
lesson-6.details: Costume sizes can be changed by assigning a percentage to the size you would like the costume to be increased by. Remember, percentages range from 0-100%. You can set a different size for each costume and each costume size increases differently depending on what its initial size is. How about you try now to make the three different costumes each a different size?

lesson-7.title: Setting Angles
lesson-7.details: You can also set the costumes to tilt at different angles. Each costume is by default set at an angle of 0 degrees. You will notice that in the example above, the first costume, ‘leaf1’, is tilted at 45° (45 degrees) while the second costume, ‘bud1’, is tilted at 10°. Costumes can be titled at any angles ranging from 0 to 360 degrees. Can you make the costumes tilt at angles higher than 90 degrees?

lesson-8.title: Coordinates
lesson-8.details: Your costume starts at x=0,y=0 on the screen. If you make the costume move 4 steps horizontally, then you do so by setting x=4. So, the x-axis is the horizontal plane. If you make the costume move 4 steps vertically, then you do so by setting y=4. So, the y-axis is the vertical plane. If you set both x=4 and y=4 then the costume will move diagonally. In the example above, the costume, leaf1, has been moved on the x-axis by moving 90 steps on the x-axis while the costume, bud1, has been moved on the y-axis by 70 steps. Can you make the costumes move forward and backward on the x-axis and upward and downward on the y-axis?

lesson-9.title: Gliding Your Costume
lesson-9.details: If you wanted to have three costumes on the screen and you would like them to be spaced apart then you can have the costumes glide on the screen. You can make your costume glide on the screen by setting the x coordinates to move n-number of steps. However, if you have more than one costume and you wish to make both of the costumes glide each time you use the glide function, you need to ensure that the costume is at the last position of x and then moves n-number of steps from there. For instance, in the example the costume, bud1, moves from (x=0,y=0) to (x=70, y=0), while the costume, petal2, moves from (x=70, y=0) to (x=140, y=0). Can you make the costumes glide vertically by changing the y-coordinates?

lesson-10.title: Speeding Things Up
lesson-10.details: So far you have learned how to glide, change costume, costume color and size, make your costumes tilt at different angles, and move your costume on the screen. All the blocks that were contained in the setup and the glide block are no longer needed as we have already learned about all the blocks that were within these two blocks. Next, we are going to explore the CSDT interface and the terms that you have studied so far in detail.

lesson-15.title: Saving Your Work
lesson-15.details:
How to save your work:

  1. Make sure you are already logged in.
  2. Choose File (top left that looks like a page folder from the right top corner)
  3. Enter a name for your project. Or enter a name that your teacher has assigned to you to enter.

lesson-17.title: Motion Blocks
lesson-17.details:
Motion Blocks

Script

  • Use Turtle Costume
  • Set size to 300%
  • Put sprite in the middle of the screen (x=0, y=0)
  • From the center, glide left 100 pixels and down 200 pixels
  • Move to the right 100, stay 200 down
  • Move to the upper left corner: left 200, up 200 from center
